body: Could you use gdb to get the bottom few stack frames as well? I suspect that the "infinite" recursion ends at some point and the origin it probably somewhere down there!

Got the same issue with the latest nightly:

```
Linux ivo-desktop 2.6.32-33-generic-pae #72-Ubuntu SMP Fri Jul 29 22:06:29 UTC 2011 i686 GNU/Linux
```


Hm, I'm unable to reproduce on a "super old" 2.6.18 kernel (Centos 5 I think), or a 2.6.32 kernel (some random Ubuntu Lucid image on EC2)

What distributions are you guys running out of curiosity? Hopefully I can reproduce as well!

in my case: ubuntu 10.10 (maverick meerkat), **i686**.

BTW, this still happens as of official 1.0.0-alpha:

```
rustc 1.0.0-alpha (44a287e6e 2015-01-08 17:03:40 -0800)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 44a287e6eb22ec3c2a687fc156813577464017f7
commit-date: 2015-01-08 17:03:40 -0800
host: i686-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.0.0-alpha
```
Hm unfortunately I can't test on a 10.10 instance because it's reach its end of life and I can't download `gcc` to build Rust programs :(
Sadly, I'm on an even older release (10.04). Is there any "easy" way we can provide you with some additional information towards the actual cause of the crash?

Would it be possible for you to build an unoptimized version of the standard library in order to improve the backtrace? Learning what the original cause of the failure would go a long way I believe, and it's probably related to `thread_local` somehow, I'm just not quite sure how!
@alexcrichton, you can point `/etc/apt/sources.list` at old-releases.ubuntu.com as a mirror (e.g., in place of us.archive.ubuntu.com) to be able to download things on EOL'd releases.

Thanks for the pointer to the old releases @geofft! I've been able to reproduce the problem and unfortunately I think that this may just end up getting chalked up a linker bug. Right now here's some version info:

```
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ uname -a
Linux ip-10-222-153-90 2.6.35-30-virtual #59-Ubuntu SMP Tue Aug 30 16:34:46 UTC 2011 i686 GNU/Linux
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ ld -v
GNU ld (GNU Binutils for Ubuntu) 2.20.51-system.20100908
```

I also downloaded a bunch of releases from http://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/binutils/ and compiled them all locally and installed them in separate directories, here's the results I got:

```
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ rustc foo.rs && ./foo
Illegal instruction
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.20.1/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
Illegal instruction
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.21.1/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
Illegal instruction
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.22/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
foo
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.23.2/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
foo
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.24/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
foo
ubuntu@ip-10-222-153-90:~$ PATH=$HOME/root-2.25/bin:$PATH rustc foo.rs && ./foo
foo
```

From this my conclusion is that this was a bug fixed in binutils 2.22. Looking at the changelog between 2.21 and 2.22 I... basically couldn't make heads or tails of it. I suspect that the `thread_local` stuff we're using is relatively new and may not have been super well supported awhile ago.

Regardless, I think that the best recommendation would be to download and install binutils 2.22 locally and use that when linking Rust programs. This doesn't look like it's a bug on Rust's side of things, so I'm going to close this. Thanks again for the report though!

confirmed with 1.0.0-beta.

```
rustc 1.0.0-beta (9854143cb 2015-04-02) (built 2015-04-02)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 9854143cba679834bc4ef932858cd5303f015a0e
commit-date: 2015-04-02
build-date: 2015-04-02
host: i686-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.0.0-beta
```

same environment as used before, rustc invoked with binutils v2.20 in the path yields (a slightly improved - note the message):

```
thread '<unknown>' has overflowed its stack
Illegal instruction
```

with binutils v2.25 in the path while invoking rustc - i get the expected result: working "hello world". :)

@alexcrichton: thanks for looking into this.
